What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course was a continuation of CHNS130 and I learned advanced vocabulary, sentence patterns, and reading/writing skills. With the daily class format and tutorial sessions, I also found that my speaking improved significantly.
Developed Chinese abilities
A better understanding of grammar structures, a lot of new vocabulary and general fluency
This course further developed my speaking and listening skills (through an immersion classroom experience) while teaching me more Chinese vocabulary and grammer.
I definitely improved my essay writing skills and fluidity in speaking Mandarin.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths: Liang laoshi is the reason why I was excited to go to class every day. She is was supportive and dedicated to our class, and it was clear that she cared about each of us. The class was really organized, we typically went chapter by chapter learning new vocab, sentence patterns, reading passages, writing, etc. The class was also highly interactive because of the small number of students so everyone had the chance to participate every day. Weaknesses: The class is definitely fast-paced, and near the beginning of the semester I remember spending a lot of time out of class reviewing the material.

Despite the virtual format, the structure was well-maintained, and I felt challenged throughout. The professors were also amazing and incredibly helpful! The only weakness is the reduced emphasis on writing characters - somewhat inevitable in a virtual environment but I felt like I needed more writing practice.
This course was very engaging and structured so as to maximize student practice of learned concepts. I always enjoyed coming to class and felt supported by the teaching team!

This course is very dense and I was constantly stressed about turning in assignments. I didn't really enjoy Mandarin the way I did in high school, it got to a point that I became less and less engaged in the class because the coursework continually stressed me. Every week we either had a major writing assignment, presentation, or assessment.... in addition to normal classwork. Within the last two weeks of the semester, we had an oral test, an oral project, and a final assessment. My parent even noticed that I was always doing Chinese homework; it felt like I didn't take any other classes at Yale. I think the work structure of this class could be organized a bit differently to include more periods focused on learning the material than constantly worrying about the next assessment/major assignment. I also feel as though my handwriting of characters drastically declined. I can recognize and read newly learned characters for the most part, but cannot write anything from memory.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the course did a good job in transitioning to a virtual format and I think the small class size helped -- everyone had an opportunity to participate every class. The lectures were interactive and breakout room speaking activities with classmates were very engaging.
I appreciated asynchronous tests on Thursdays and the variety of activities we had for tutorials and 2-on-1 sessions, and overall think the course was fantastically adapted to the virtual environment

Switching to a project on Thursdays rather than the normal class was a welcome break from Zoom and always enjoyable. In addition, they gave me the chance to get to know my classmates better. In general, breakout rooms were also used very effectively for classroom exercises and speaking practice.
I liked the use of slides and padlet! I also like the partner work, but it could be less frequent.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Definitely, but if you are willing to put in the time and effort. I learned so many new words/grammar patterns, improved my speaking, and feel more comfortable reading/writing. The class definitely pays off and I also had such a good time with Liang laoshi and classmates every day.
Yes

Yes!! Requires a lot of work, but is well worth it if you like learning Chinese - I saw huge improvement and learned a lot of new vocabulary. The course was fantastically well managed for a virtual one as well. Take it

Yes! The workload is manageable and the instructors in the department are all great. You are incredibly supported in your learning process and the material is taught in such a way that class is often fun!
They should take the course if they really like Mandarin and don't mind dedicating a lot of time to work.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly virtual Tutorials are one-on-one meetings with a graduate student to practice speaking.
Asynchronous collaboration
N/A
